summary: to all game of thrones fandom: we can all disagree on things, stan that character or the other, ship this or that, that’s all...
body: to all game of thrones fandom: we can all disagree on things, stan that character or the other, ship this or that, that’s all fine… we even cross lines and have insane discourses and make hateful posts. but my grandparents, mainly my grandfather, is being dragged into a fandom discourse as a “gross man” because @sayruq and @cmollyo want to make a point. can you guys please learn to have boundaries? don’t fucking insult people’s families because they disagree with you, don’t fucking insult people’s families when you don’t know anything about them. it’s the second time people shit on my grandparents. THE SECOND TIME.

THE SECOND TIME.

THE SECOND TIME.

blog.name: fedonciadale
blog.title: FedonCiadale
blog.description: Fantasy aficionado since I read Tolkien in my teenage years. I still love Tolkien but I am also into other works. I love ASOIAF (books) and GoT (Show). I also like Brandon Sanderson, Lois McMaster Bujold, in short in my free time it's fantasy...Header by courtesy of ragekitn!

summary: Hey, Thanks for answering my question and showing me that d@ny & storm meta. I intend to portray jon as a heroic but also...
question: Hey, Thanks for answering my question and showing me that d@ny & storm meta. I intend to portray jon as a heroic but also destructive savior where if he is not calm he will cause more destruction than the enemy, just like a dragon does, so he represents both wind(unstoppable) and storm(devastating). I am not very well versed with lotr so could you tell me if bloodraven is more like saruman or an evil gandalf or an entirely different figure? I treat him as a friend of humanity but not the heroes.
answer:
Hi there!

I do think that any wielder of magic in ASOIAF has a destructive force as well. So, Jon destroying some things while saving the world from Euron makes sense to me.

Bloodraven…. Well, I do think he is more of a Saruman figure, although in a way he is not. Tolkien made no secret about Saruman’s fall. We learn about Saruman and his own evil agenda when Gandalf tells everyone at Elrond’s council how they were betrayed. So there is no element of surprise there, not really.

With Bloodraven I would say that the motives are similar to Saruman. If my hunch is right he was recruited by the Children of the Forest and managed to dupe them. He then made Euron his apprentice, but he went rogue and then Bloodraven reached out to Bran. But his motives are not selfless and my suspicion is that he wants to use the magic that was let lose with the re-emerging of the WW to get immortality. He might be after a young, male Targ he can inhabit, and my suspicion is, that he is after Jon. He might also be the person who is behind Aegon’s V obsession with dragons and the tragedy of Summerhall. So his motives are selfish and in this regard he is like Saruman, only it is not that obvious to the reader.

An evil Gandalf would not necessarily be selfish, but more like a smaller “dark lord”, in a way more frightening and more surreal than Saruman. So I think I would stick to Saruman as a parallel, even though Bloodraven’s treason is not as easily seen as Saruman’s.

Thanks for the ask!

tags: Jon Snow is not a Gary Stue
Jon Snow is not a self-insert by GRRM
Jon Snow is not a Northern fool
the real Jon Snow defence squad
summary: Do you think Jon Snow is a Gary Stue? Part of the fandom already saw a little resemblance between young Georgie with Kit's...
question: Do you think Jon Snow is a Gary Stue? Part of the fandom already saw a little resemblance between young Georgie with Kit's appearence, both Jon and George have a kink for redheads, and on the surface Jon seems like a typical Gary Stue, but I don't know... I kinda see why people might say that, but I'm not entirely sure. What do you think?  It is clear that George self inserts in Jon (at least a little), which I find personally, cute? Not even a great author like GRRM can escape that tendency...
answer:
Dear nonny,

definitely not. For once, although the ressemblance of young George with Kit is there, this particular post is a crackpost. I would remind you that BookJon has no ressemblance to George, even to young George. His face is long and stern, and he has no curls. Here is a picture from a calendar of ice and fire (sorry for the bad quality).

and here is a link to the art by amoka (x), which shows pretty much how Jon looks like in the books. So, sry, not sry, George does not look like Jon, and he himself said that if he is anyone he is Samwell Tarly… (x), bookloving, fat Samwell Tarly.

You know, it is funny that young George has a resemblance to Kit, but this does not prove anything, least of all that Jon is a Gary Stue.

Honestly, - and this is not directed at you, nonny - people should learn to seperate what is an actual argument (for instance quotes and foreshadowing from the books or the show) and what is crack and funny coincidence. I mean GRRM could not possibly know that Kit Harrington would play his Jon Snow when he published his first book in 1993….

You know that is the same kind of argument that is used by Da€nerys stans: GRRM’s family lost their fortune and house and as a child he had the feeling that he was robbed, and therefore he could not write anything else but a Targ restoration. Honestly? This is not how writing and literature works.

Yes, of course writers let their own experience flow into the writing, but good writers transcend this and I sincerely doubt that GRRM self-inserts very much into any of his characters. I would just alert you to the fact that he has several very different female characters that are all great and believable in their own way - the only part he does not get is female friendship, but so be it, otherwise the range of his women is spectacular.

So, I wouldn’t say GRRM self-inserts much into Jon apart from maybe channeling some of his experience and feelings into the character, but Jon is not a Gary Stue.

People say that he has it easy (where, honestly where?) and that he has a plot armour… But even that is not true. There are several reasons that Jon dies and will be ressurrected and none of them is about plot armour.

I didn’t mean to get all riled up about this, in particular because yours was an honest question. So please, bear with me, that I am a bit impatient with Jon ridicule. Jon Snow is my favourite character in the books, and BookJon is smart and clever and a well-fleshed character who has his faults. And I hate him being misrepresented as cinnamon roll whose only purpose is to bring Da€nerys to the good side, or a Gary Stue who has it easy, or a Northern fool who gives up the North for love and cheats Sansa of her birthright. None of this is Jon. Somehow people think he got everything handled on a platter? Like when he lost Ygritte? When he was killed? When he fought in the Battle of the Bastards? When he is ready to do everything for the survival of the North!

 I can’t wait for season 8… Then I probably will have to defend Jon against other accusations, but I’ll gladly do this as long as I don’t get any more ‘cinnamon roll’ - Jon Snow posts on my dash.

Thanks for the ask!

summary: You are one of my favorite Jonsa bloggers, and I loved your answer to the other anon on Jon's resurrection. It's interesting to...
question: You are one of my favorite Jonsa bloggers, and I loved your answer to the other anon on Jon's resurrection. It's interesting to think how this will go in the books.  While I don't know whether we'll get Jon in Ghost POV, I think we will definitely see a fight between Ghost and Ramsey's dogs.  This is foreshadowed in the first book when Jon gives Ghost half a honeyed chicken, and Ghost fends off a black dog looking to take the chicken. A honeyed chicken sounds like slang for names for girls.
answer:
(2)  Here’s the full quote:  "Dogs moved between the tables, trailing after the serving girls. One of them, a black mongrel bitch with long yellow eyes, caught a scent of the chicken. She stopped and edged under the bench to get a share. Jon watched the confrontation. The bitch growled low in her throat and moved closer. Ghost looked up, silent, and fixed the dog with those hot red eyes. The bitch snapped an angry challenge. She was three times the size of the direwolf pup. Ghost did not move.      

(3)  He stood over his prize and opened his mouth, baring his fangs. The bitch tensed, barked again, then thought better of this fight. She turned and slunk away, with one last defiant snap to save her pride. Ghost went back to his meal.“  In terms of how we will know Jon loves Sansa, I think Jon’s resurrection will be more traumatic in the books.

(4) We may get Jon’s POV that he has inappropriate feelings for Sansa, but the reader won’t be able to tell whether this is a side effect of the resurrection. Then, Jon will go to see Dany, and his POV will be hidden. The audience may even root for him to fall in love with Dany to stop his inappropriate feelings for Sansa. It may seem like he is getting over his “weird” Sansa feelings. Then, R+L=J will be revealed   along with the truth that Jon has always loved Sansa. Would love any thoughts?  

Dear nonny,

if I remember correctly GRRM himself also wanted a dog-wolves fight in season 4, the last season he was involved in - a possible foreshadowing of Jon’s fight with Ramsay. I must admit that I love Jon in Ghost so much that I wrote a series of ficlet about this, how it might play out. I would be so excited about Jon fighting in Ghost against Ramsay’s dogs!

I would also alert you to the fact that there is another instance of ‘Jon’ fighting over a bird:

"That’s the real king of this castle right there,” one of the gold cloaks had told her. “Older than sin and twice as mean. One time, the king was feasting the queen’s father, and that black bastard hopped up on the table and snatched a roast quail right out of Lord Tywin’s fingers. Robert laughed so hard he like to burst. You stay away from that one, child.” (AGOT, Arya III)

That black cat Arya chases in the Red Keep is a Jon stand-in. And here we have a small bird that will be snatched from a Lannister. So, Jon probably will save Sansa from Ramsay’s dogs and from the Lannisters (if there will be a kidnapping).

As for how Jonsa will play out after his ressurection I can easily picture your scenario. I guess we could get Jon being in confusion about who is Sansa and mixing her up with Ygritte and this would play into the depiction of Political Jon. As you said, the reader probably would root for Jon to fall for Dany to get rid of his feelings for Sansa. And this bias would lead to the reader not realising that something is off until the rug is pulled under him/her. I do think this is a very likely scenario and one which I would thoroughly enjoy. I really would like to have TWOW right now!

Thanks for your thoughts and your ask! I really appreciate the compliment and I’m glad you like my blog!

reblog.comment:
(2)  Here’s the full quote:  "Dogs moved between the tables, trailing after the serving girls. One of them, a black mongrel bitch with long yellow eyes, caught a scent of the chicken. She stopped and edged under the bench to get a share. Jon watched the confrontation. The bitch growled low in her throat and moved closer. Ghost looked up, silent, and fixed the dog with those hot red eyes. The bitch snapped an angry challenge. She was three times the size of the direwolf pup. Ghost did not move.      

(3)  He stood over his prize and opened his mouth, baring his fangs. The bitch tensed, barked again, then thought better of this fight. She turned and slunk away, with one last defiant snap to save her pride. Ghost went back to his meal.“  In terms of how we will know Jon loves Sansa, I think Jon’s resurrection will be more traumatic in the books.

(4) We may get Jon’s POV that he has inappropriate feelings for Sansa, but the reader won’t be able to tell whether this is a side effect of the resurrection. Then, Jon will go to see Dany, and his POV will be hidden. The audience may even root for him to fall in love with Dany to stop his inappropriate feelings for Sansa. It may seem like he is getting over his “weird” Sansa feelings. Then, R+L=J will be revealed   along with the truth that Jon has always loved Sansa. Would love any thoughts?

blog.name: odroslore
blog.title: Odros Lore
blog.description: We are enthusiastic and fantasy oriented people. We will deliver you all the stories and lore you need for your favorite fantasy universe, TV series, books, comics, and games.

summary: Game of Thrones Lore: Story of House Harte
title: Game of Thrones Lore: Story of House Harte
excerpt: House Harte is a noble house from the crownlands. The Hartes are sworn directly to House Baratheon of King's Landing. According to semi-canon sources, they blazon their arms with three red hart's heads caboshed on a white bend on vair.

- What is it you would have me see?
- The way the world is made.

blog.name: fortunatelylori
blog.title: Thoughts on the verge
blog.description:
Pretty much Game of Throne and Jonsa all day, every day. 
Avatar and header by @ragekitn

summary: Hey lori (is that the name you go by here? Or should we use your full url?), I'm curious if you think GRRM's question "What...
question: Hey lori (is that the name you go by here? Or should we use your full url?), I'm curious if you think GRRM's question "What about the orc babies?" will he answered a 3rd time. As I count it, the question of what to do with the children of your enemy comes up with Elia's children and Robert/Tywin obviously, and then a little bit with Mance's child and Stannis. As much as I hate the b0atie theory, it could potentially act as a 3rd time the question is asked, and now we get an answer from our king.
answer:
Hey, nonnie!

You can call me fortunatelylori or lori or whatever  you like. Just make it something nice. :)

I’ve actually been thinking about the  “What about the orc babies?” question a lot. I just don’t think b0atie is the answer to that question. Most importantly, this would be Jon’s kid so he would have a vested interest in keeping him safe. He wouldn’t be one of Aragon’s orcs. 

I also think it’s a mistake to take everything GRRM says literally. GRRM’s question hankers back to the fall-out of war and how rulers choose to handle the different factions that fought in that war. Meaning, how much punishment is to be dealt to the people that fought on the wrong side and how far should a ruler go in order to ensure peace and the healing of a fractured society. At it’s core this is a huge philosophical question, one we struggle with even in our real world. The way a leader decides to make peace is as important as the reasons why he goes to war. 

It’s also problematic to try to apply the rule of three unilaterally to everything in ASOIAF. Yes, GRRM uses the rule of three A LOT (too much in my opinion) but I don’t think it’s beneficial to try to apply that rule to every and all plot points. 

Aside from the things you mentioned, there are many more examples in the ASOIAF of the “orc babies” dilemma: 

Jon is a prime example of this. He is the son of the Targareyen who lost the war, one of the last 3 survivors of a dynasty that caused havoc and untold destruction to Westeros for centuries. What is GRRM’s answer to that? Ned takes Jon home with him and raises him as one of his own children. In turn, Jon grows up embracing Stark values and code of conduct, proving that nurture can in many ways supersede nature. 

D*ny is another example of a baby orc. Robert Baratheon wants to kill a young, defenseless girl to eliminate a risk he still doesn’t know exists. And in doing so, he actually ensures that Khal Drogo decides to go to war. Which is ironic as hell. 

Ned opposes that decision, finding it cruel and cowardly. Would Westeros have been better served had Robert’s plot of killing D*ny succeeded? Perhaps. But would it have been the right thing to do at the time, with the information he had? Perhaps if he had left well enough alone, D*ny would still be Khaleesi to Khal Drogo, there would be no dragons and the Dothraki wouldn’t have eventually crossed the Narrow Sea. 

Jon, himself, faces his own “baby orcs” dilemma first with the Wildlings, whom he decides to bring into the fold instead of continuing to fight them and then, in season 7, with the pardoning of Alys Karstark and Ned Umber. Alys and Ned are very much baby orcs, blameless but the children of people who betrayed House Stark and caused harm. Jon’s answer to that is: 

Jon: Yesterday’s wars don’t matter. 

As one baby orc to another, Jon brings Alys and Ned back into the fold hoping that nurture will supersede nature in their case as well. 

And if Jon ends up King of Westeros, he will, most likely, be facing yet another “baby orcs” dilemma with the Unsullied and the Dothraki. Even if he manages to defeat D*ny and rid the world of dragons, it’s very probable that at least part of the Unsullied army and the Dothraki hoards will survive. 

What will he do with them? Execute all of them? Ship them off to Essos? Try to bring them into the fold as well, as he did with the Wildlings? Or will he be plagued by Dothraki blood riders raiding and pillaging Westeros through out his reign? 

That’s, to my mid, the real essence of GRRM’s question. And that’s vastly more interesting and challenging than deciding what to do with a fictional b0atie. :)

Thanks for the ask!

summary: “Your seed is still inside me and warm. By night I might have your child, Jaime. You’ve begged for us to be never apart. Now...
body:
Ch. 4: Lioness Ascending

“Your seed is still inside me and warm. By night I might have your child, Jaime. You’ve begged for us to be never apart. Now that we will never be, now that we have the freedom, you keep telling me your doubts. Every uncertainty you speak of with regards to my reign takes you another league away from me. You swore to fight until only the two of us are left in this world. Has that changed?”

The latest update of Our Kingdom, available on AO3. Private fic.

Ch. 4: Lioness Ascending

“Your seed is still inside me and warm. By night I might have your child, Jaime. You’ve begged for us to be never apart. Now that we will never be, now that we have the freedom, you keep telling me your doubts. Every uncertainty you speak of with regards to my reign takes you another league away from me. You swore to fight until only the two of us are left in this world. Has that changed?”

The latest update of Our Kingdom, available on AO3. Private fic.

blog.description: HE LOVED HER AND SHE LOVED HIM

summary:
Some Nights
My heart’s breaking for my sister and the con that she called love
But then I look into my nephew’s eyes
Man you...
body:
Some Nights

My heart’s breaking for my sister and the con that she called love

But then I look into my nephew’s eyes

Man you wouldn’t believe the most amazing things

That can come from some terrible lies

blog.description: An automated feed for Jon x Arya fics posted on AO3.

summary: To Play The Game
title: To Play The Game
description:
by thewriterthatwaspromised

The long night is almost upon them- still the Game of Thrones wages on. On the brink of two wars in which both results depend on the outcome of each other, Jon Snow struggles with his growing feelings for his “half-sister” Sansa Stark. Unbeknowingly to him, she two struggles with the same feelings. When a secret is finally revealed to the Stark Clan which allows Jon and Sansa to drop all pretense and face the true nature of their relationship, the others arrive- and everything goes to hell.

Words: 2165, Chapters: 1/1, Language: English

  • Fandoms: Game of Thrones (TV)
  • Rating: Mature
  • Warnings: Major Character Death
  • Categories: Multi
  • Characters: Jon Snow, Jon Snow | Aegon Targaryen, Sansa Stark, Arya Stark, Bran Stark, Daenerys Targaryen, Samwell Tarly, Jamie Lannister, Gilly Craster, Davos Seaworth, Tyrion Lannister, Varys, Brienne Tarth - Character, Missandei
  • Relationships: Jon Snow/Sansa Stark, Jon Snow/Arya Stark, Jon Snow/Daenerys Targaryen
  • Additional Tags: jonsa, Jon and Sansa - Freeform, Game of Thrones - Freeform, a song of ice and fire - Freeform, George R R Martin, GRMM
